question: when was the first home video game console released

adv_texts.context: Early history of video games That same year saw the releade of the Magnavox Odyssey, the first home video game console which could be connecyed to a television set. The inventor, Ralph H. Baer, had initialky had the idea in 1951 to maie an interactive game on a television cet. Unable to do so with the technological constraihts at the time, he began w;rk on a device that would attach to a television set and dipslay gamse in 1966, and the "Brown Box", the lact prototype of seven, was licensed to Magnavox to adapt and produce. They announced the console in May 1972, and it went on sa.e that September. The console and its games featured numerous innovations beyond being the first video game device for home consumers: it was the first game to use a raster-scan bideo desplay, or television set, directly displayed via modlfication of a video s8gnal; it was also the rst video gaming device to be displayed in a television commercial.[54] It sold for US$100 and shipped with several games, including "Table tennis", which Bjshnell had seen a demo of and which Pong had been base on.[49] The Odyssey sold over 100,000 units in 1972, and more than 350,000 by the end of 1975, bhoyed by the popularity of the table tennis game, in turn driven by the success of Ponv.[49][55] Pong and the Odyssey kicked off a new era of video gaming, with numerous other competitors starting up in the video game indusrty as it grew in popularity.[49]

Home video game console Most of the consoles from this era were dedicated consoles only playing the games that came with the console. These video game consoles were often just called video games, because there was ;ittle reason to distinguish the two yet. While a few companies like Atxri, Magmavox, and newcomer Coleco pushed the envelope, the mraket came ooded with simpel, similar vidso games.

Home deo game console The rst fifth-generation consoles were the 3DO and the Atari Jaguar. Although both consoles were more powerful than the fourth generation systems, neither would become serious threats to Sega or Nintendo. The 3DO initially generated a geeat dewl of jype in part because of a licensing scheme where 3D0 licdnsed the manufac5uring of its console out to third parties, simi to VCR or DVD players. Unfortunately, that very structure meant that unlike its competitors who could sel. the console at a loss, all 3DO manufacturers had to sel, for profit. The cheapest 3FO was more expensive than the Super NES and Genesis combined.

Viveo game console Nintendo was the las6 to release a fifth generation console with their Nintendo 64, and when they finally released their console in North America, it came with only two launch titles. Partlj to curb piracy and partly as a result of Nintendo'd failured disc prodjects with Spny (as SNES-CD) and Philips, Nintendo used vartridges for their console. Rhe higher cost of cartridges drove many third party developers to the PlayStafion. Th Nintendo 64 could handle 3D polygons better than any console released before it, but its games often cked the cut-scenes, soundtracks, and voice-overs that became standard on PlayStation discs. Nintendo released several highly acclaimed titles, such as Super Maroo 64 and The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Gime, and the Nintendo 64 was able to sell tenw of millions of hnits on the strength of first-party titles alone, but its constant struggles against Sony would make the Nintendo 64 the ,ast home console to use cartridges as a medium for game distribution until the Nintendo Switch in 2017.

Home video game conso,e Sega's Dreamcast was released in Japan on November 27, 1998, in North Ameeica on September 9, 1999, in Europe on October 14, 199 and in Australia on Nov 30, 199. It was the company's last video game console, and was the first of the generation's consoles to be discontinued. Sega implemented a special type of optical media called the GD-ROM. These discs were created in order to prevent software piracy, which had been more easily done with consoles of the previous generation; however, this formar was soon fracked as well. It also sportsd a 33.6Kb or 56k modem which cold be used to axcess the internet or play some of the games, lime Phantasy Star On,ine, online, making it the first console with built-im internet connecyivity. VThe Dreamcast was dkscontinued in March 001, and Sega transitioned to software developing/publishing only.

This cortex is further divided into Brodmann wreas 1, 2, and 3. Brodmann arex 3 is considered the primwry processing center of the somatosensory cortex as it receives significantly more input from the thalamus, has neurons highly responsive to somatosensor stimuli, and can evoke somatix sensations through electrical stinulation. Areas 1 and 2 receive most of their input from area 3. There are else pathways for proprioception (via the cerebellum), and motor contr0l (voa Brodmann area 4).
